results.title: ‘Aboriginal kitsch’ Jedda plate
results.brief_description: Due to Jedda’s popularity and interest in Aboriginal ‘kitsch’ and culture, Arrernte actress Kunoth-Monks and Jedda became entwined. But she never acted again, instead becoming an advocate for Australia’s First Peoples.
results.description: Memorabilia ceramic plate featuring an illustrated portrait of Rosalie Kunoth-Monks from the film Jedda. Plate is round with illustration printed in centre in shades of browns on a creamy white background. Verso of plate is white with two holes related to hainging of plate.
description_for_label: Memorabilia ceramic plate featuring an illustrated portrait of Rosalie Kunoth-Monks from the film Jedda. Plate is round with illustration printed in centre in shades of browns on a creamy white background. Verso of plate is white with two holes related to hainging of plate.

results.title: Prisoner theme 7-inch vinyl single
results.brief_description: Prisoner packed a punch when it premiered in 1979. Set in the fictional suburb of Wentworth, the female-centred prison drama reverberated around the world, spawning international adaptations and a massive cult following.
results.description:
Vinyl record “On The Inside - The Original TV Theme From Prisoner Cell Block H” - Lynne Hamilton

results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: David spends a happy day at the zoo looking at and feeding all the animals. When he returns home, he makes a zoo of his own. The animals come to life and the monkeys imprison the keeper and begin to release the other animals. Disaster threatens but Elsie the elephant comes to the rescue. Cast: Aaron Judah. Narration: Aaron Judah. Music: Alan Lane.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films

results.title: The Moving Record
results.creator_credit: Robert Rothols and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: A look at how film has been used to portray agriculture in Australia and particularly in Victoria between 1913 and 1985, and how film makers strengthened certain myths about city and country life. This compilation of old film footage was put together for the 150th anniversary of Victoria. Narrated by Sir Eric Pearce.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Rothols and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: Film of circles, squares, triangles, lines and dots (TEFC)
results.brief_description: An example of hand drawn film using spirit based pen, done by an autistic teenager, showing capacity for highly detailed and controlled work.

results.title: Warrah
results.brief_description: Warrah was filmed in the coastal sandstone bush of the Hawkesbury River area in NSW. It is a film of rock, foliage, angophoras, rock pools, the movement of shadows, light reflected from water and reflections of trees and clouds in rock pools. The soundtrack of this 3-colour separation film is an unaltered recording of insects and choruses of kookaburras.

results.title: Two-colour separation studies
results.brief_description: A variety of still life, landscape and portrait studies in both red/green and orange/blue systems are accompanied by a detailed explanation by Arthur Cantrill of the process and history of the two colour separation system. Includes a simulation of the Kinemacolour process which alternated red and green frames.
